categories.name: Fans
categories.description: Moves that spread the cards out in a circular or semi-circular fashion.

categories.name: One-handed moves (no cuts)
categories.description: Moves performed using only one hand (can be either hand). No cuts allowed.

categories.name: One-handed cuts
categories.description: Cuts performed using only one hand (can be either hand).

categories.name: Aerials
categories.description: Moves where a single card or more flies through the air

categories.name: Moves that use Angel
categories.description: Moves involving one card or more being stuck to or balanced on the fingertips, ala Angel/Morning Star

categories.name: Moves using only one card
categories.description: Do we really have to explain this?

categories.name: Moves where only one card moves
categories.description: This refers to a move where the rest of the deck is stationary, except for one card that moves as part of the flourish. Not to be confused with Moves using only one card.

categories.name: Corner spin moves
categories.description: Any move where a single card or more is held by the fingers or by other forms of support at two opposite corners, and that packet completes at least one full 360-degree spin around the diagonal axis.

categories.name: 3 Packet Moves
categories.description: See title. Note: closing packets and then introducing new packets later on during the flourish is not allowed. Only 3 packets must be in play throughout the duration of the move.

categories.name: 4 Packet moves.
categories.description: See title. Note: closing packets and then introducing new packets later on during the flourish is not allowed. Only 4 packets must be in play throughout the duration of the move.

categories.name: 5 Packet Moves
categories.description: See title. Note: closing packets and then introducing new packets later on during the flourish is not allowed. Only 4 packets must be in play throughout the duration of the move.

categories.name: Two-handed 2 Packet Moves
categories.description: Moves that use only two packets. Moves performed only using one hand are not allowed, nor two-handed versions of pre-existing one-handed moves (we know you were thinking it).

categories.name: Full deck moves
categories.description: Moves where the entire deck is manipulated as a single block. The deck cannot be separated into multiple portions, and no overt fanning/spreading of the deck is allowed. However, if the deck becomes slightly unsquare as a result of the handling of the move, then that is fine.

categories.name: Springs & Cascades
categories.description: Moves that involve a spring mechanic, OR moves involving many cards cascading/flowing from one position to another in smooth succession.

categories.name: Front-Facing Moves
categories.description: Moves where the cardist's hands hold the cards palm-out in front of their body.

categories.name: 2D Displays
categories.description: Displays that are ‘flat’. Fans are not allowed.

categories.name: 3D Structures and Shapes
categories.description: Formations where packets are placed against each other to create a type of structure or shape. 2D/Flat displays are not allowed

categories.name: Moves using a spread
categories.description: Any move that *functionally* involves a spread. Just throwing a spread into any random move doesn’t count. But you knew that, right?

categories.name: Looping moves (3 Reps)
categories.description: Moves where an action or sequence is repeated at least 3 times. Note: merely doing a move 3 times does not count. The repeating mechanic must be performed *before* the move closes.

categories.name: Isolations
categories.description: Moves that either: 1) create the overt appearance of one or more cards/packet being suspended momentarily in space, or: 2) cause one or more cards/packets to move around a fixed point in space.

categories.name: Card shots
categories.description: Moves where a card is propelled through the air and then caught.

categories.name: Moves that use a Faro shuffle
categories.description: Do we really need to explain this?

categories.name: Table/surface moves
categories.description: Moves that require the use of a table or other surface to work. (Note: simply placing the deck on a surface and giving it a basic cut/shuffle is not allowed. I can’t believe we actually have to mention this.)

categories.name: Dan and Dave moves
categories.description: Moves created by Dan and/or Dave Buck

categories.name: Virtuoso moves
categories.description: Moves created by any current or former members of the group Virtuoso

categories.name: Fontaine moves
description: • are original creations taught by cardists on the Fontaine Cards YouTube channel, or
• are taught on the Cardistry High download

categories.name: New Deck Order/School of Cardistry moves
categories.description: Moves that: 1) have been created by Jaspas Deck, or 2) are original creations taught by cardists through New Deck Order Free/Premium Tutorials

categories.name: Dealersgrip moves
categories.description: Original moves that have been created or taught by any past and present members of Dealersgrip, and that have been published through Dealersgrip.

categories.name: French moves
categories.description: Moves by cardists hailing from any part of France.

categories.name: Superhandz/Handlordz moves (XCM)
description: • created by De’vo vom Schattenreich or Jerry Cestkowski,
• created by card handlers heavily associated with Superhandz/Handlordz, or
• that are a trademark staple of the ‘XCM’ style of card handling

categories.name: Moves using your breath
categories.description: Moves that use one’s breath to actively manipulate one card or more at any point during the flourish.

categories.name: Do the same move in both hands
categories.description: Do we really have to explain this?

categories.name: Moves that bend the deck
categories.description: Moves that functionally employ the bending of many cards to work.

categories.name: Stunts/High Risk moves
categories.description: Big, showy moves that have a higher than normal chance of failure. In other words: go big or go home.

categories.name: Theory11 Moves
categories.description: Original moves by cardists that have been published through Theory11. (Note: this only refers to major releases, so moves from The Wire are not allowed.)

categories.name: Interlock moves
categories.description: Moves that employ the ‘Interlock’ principle.

categories.name: Original moves
categories.description: Moves that the player has created. For verification's sake, this has to be a move that has either been performed or taught on a public video before.

categories.name: Moves by your opponent
categories.description: Moves that the player’s opponent has created. For verification's sake, this has to be a move that has either been performed or taught on a public video before.

categories.name: Moves using your face
categories.description: Moves that involve the use of any part of the face as an essential part of the flourish.

categories.name: Moves using the box
categories.description: Moves that incorporate the box into the flourish.

categories.name: Moves using your feet/legs
categories.description: Moves that involve the use of any part of the feet or legs as an essential part of the flourish.

categories.name: Moves using your arm(s)
categories.description: Moves that involve the use of any part of the arm, from the wrist upwards, as an essential part of the flourish.

categories.name: Swedish moves
categories.description: Moves created by cardists hailing from Sweden.

categories.name: Vietnamese moves
categories.description: Moves created by cardists hailing from Vietnam.

categories.name: Israeli moves
categories.description: Moves created by cardists hailing from Israel.

categories.name: Chinese moves
categories.description: Moves created by cardists hailing from China.

categories.name: Flips
categories.description: Moves where one or more cards rotate at least 360 degrees, through the air, around either the vertical or horizontal axis

categories.name: Moves from viral cardistry videos
categories.description: Moves that have appeared in any video that has broken through into the mainstream and has been seen by a significant number of non-cardists. (So basically, any cardistry video or GIF that’s hit the front page of reddit.)

categories.name: Twirls
categories.description: Moves where a single card or more is spun deftly by the fingers in a fluttering motion.

categories.name: Tudor moves
categories.description: Moves created by the OG, Brian Tudor.

categories.name: Japanese moves
categories.description: Moves created by cardists hailing from Japan.

categories.name: Competition moves
categories.description: Moves that have appeared in any of the official Round entries of past and/or current cardistry competitions, such as WKC, CCC, ICO, etc..

categories.name: Moves with a one-syllable name
categories.description: This sentence has ten syllables in it.

categories.name: Moves named after people
categories.description: Moves that feature the name of a person in the title.

categories.name: Singaporean moves
categories.description: Moves created by cardists hailing from Singapore.

categories.name: Backhanded moves
categories.description: Moves where one card or more is placed on and manipulated by the back of one’s hand.

categories.name: Sybil Variations
categories.description: Variations of moves employing the ‘Sybil’ mechanic.

categories.name: Moves named after brands
categories.description: Moves that feature the name of brands in the title.

categories.name: Moves starting with A
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter A.

categories.name: Moves starting with B
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter B.

categories.name: Moves starting with C
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter C.

categories.name: Moves starting with D
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter D.

categories.name: Moves starting with E
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter E.

categories.name: Moves starting with F
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter F.

categories.name: Moves starting with G
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter G.

categories.name: Moves starting with H
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter H.

categories.name: Moves starting with I
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter I. (Note: "Isolation" isn’t a move. It’s a category.)

categories.name: Moves starting with J
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter J.

categories.name: Moves starting with K
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter K.

categories.name: Moves starting with L
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter L.

categories.name: Moves starting with M
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter M.

categories.name: Moves starting with N
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter N.

categories.name: Moves starting with O
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter O.

categories.name: Moves starting with P
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter P.

categories.name: Moves starting with Q
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter Q.

categories.name: Moves starting with R
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter R.

categories.name: Moves starting with S
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter S.

categories.name: Moves starting with T
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter T.

categories.name: Moves starting with U
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter U.

categories.name: Moves starting with V
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter V.

categories.name: Moves starting with W
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter W.

categories.name: Moves starting with X
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter X. Note: "XCM" isn't a move. It's a performing style.

categories.name: Moves starting with Y
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter Y.

categories.name: Moves starting with Z
categories.description: Moves that have a title starting with the letter Z. (Note: Z-grip isn’t a move. It’s just shorthand for the relative position of three packets to each other.)

categories.name: Norwegian moves
categories.description: Moves created by cardists hailing from Norway.

categories.name: Moves that use balance
categories.description: Moves where one card or more is placed in a precarious, balanced position: either on the finger(s) or on other card(s).

categories.name: Moves that use your clothing
categories.description: Moves that functionally involve your clothing to manipulate the cards.

categories.name: Moves intergrating other objects
categories.description: Moves that use non-card items around you to manipulate the cards.

categories.name: North American moves
categories.description: Moves created by cardists hailing from North America.

categories.name: Russian moves
categories.description: Moves created by cardists hailing from Russia.

categories.name: Indian moves
categories.description: Moves created by cardists hailing from India.

categories.name: European moves
categories.description: Moves created by cardists hailing from Europe.

categories.name: New Zealand moves
categories.description: Moves created by cardists hailing from New Zealand.

categories.name: Australian moves
categories.description: Moves created by cardists hailing from Australia.

categories.name: East Coast USA moves
categories.description: Moves created by cardists hailing from the East Coast of the USA.

categories.name: West Coast USA moves
categories.description: Moves created by cardists hailing from the West Coast of the USA.

categories.name: Midwest USA moves
categories.description: Moves created by cardists hailing from the Midwest of the USA.

categories.name: Danish moves
categories.description: Moves created by cardists hailing from Denmark.

categories.name: Moves by Levin, Slevin, or Kevin
categories.description: Moves created by either Tobias Levin, Eliot Slevin, or Kevin Ho.

categories.name: Moves named after food
categories.description: Moves that have the name of a type of food in the title.

categories.name: Moves by female cardists
categories.description: Moves created by any female cardist.

categories.name: Taiwanese moves
categories.description: Moves created by cardists hailing from Taiwan.

categories.name: Moves that are "bae"
categories.description: Moves that are the main subject of any instagram @[MOVENAME]_is_bae account

categories.name: Moves with numbers in the title
categories.description: (Hint: a lot of these are ‘sequels’)

categories.name: Cardistry Touch moves
description: • Moves created by Dimitri Arleri or Ladislas Toubart,
• original creations showcased in performance videos published by Cardistry Touch, or
• moves taught in any Cardistry Touch EP.

categories.name: Korean moves
categories.description: Moves created by cardists hailing from Korea.

categories.name: Moves featured on BCA
categories.description: Any move that has been featured (in video format) on the @bestcardistalive Instagram account.

categories.name: Move of the Year nominees
categories.description: Any move that has been nominated for the Flourish/Move of the Year award at any past or current Cardistry-Con.

categories.name: Video of the Year moves
categories.description: Any move that has appeared in any past or current Video of the Year Cardistry-Con Award-winning video.

categories.name: Moves from books
categories.description: Moves that have been published and taught in printed form. This includes (lecture) notes and eBooks, as well as flourishes that have been taught in magic books and other non-cardist targeted works; however, the player must cite their source when deciding on which move they will be performing. (If they’re found to be full of BS, then they will be banned from playing Showoff for life. Heh.)

categories.name: DVD/VHS moves
categories.description: Moves that have been published and taught on DVD or VHS tapes. This includes flourishes taught on magic DVD/VHS’s; however, the player must cite their source when deciding on which move they will be performing. (If they’re found to be full of BS, then they will be banned from playing Showoff for life. Heh.)

categories.name: Anyone moves
categories.description: Original moves that have been created or taught by any past and present members of Anyone, and that have been published through Anyone.

categories.name: Canadian moves
categories.description: Moves by cardists hailing from Canada

modifiers.name: using the opposite hand(s)
modifiers.description: The move must now be handled using the opposite hands that the player normally uses - for example, if it's a cut where the right hand is dominant and the left hand is lower, then the hands must be swapped.

modifiers.name: but it can't be a cut
modifiers.description: Self-explanatory

modifiers.name: but you can’t use your thumb
modifiers.description: Self-explanatory

modifiers.name: and finish with a T.G Deck Flip
modifiers.description: After doing the round's move, the player must then execute a full (360-degree) deck flip. If any cards are dropped or the move does not complete a 360-degree rotation, then it is considered a failure

modifiers.name: without looking
modifiers.description: The player must close their eyes and not peek while performing the round's move

modifiers.name: behind your back
modifiers.description: The move must be performed with the card held behind the player's back

modifiers.name: holding the cards high above your head
modifiers.description: The move must be performed with both arms straight up above the player's head

modifiers.name: 3 times in a row
modifiers.description: The move must be performed perfectly, without dropping any cards, 3 times in succession

modifiers.name: without changing the order of the deck
modifiers.description: The player must choose and perform a move fitting the round's category that subsequently does not change the order of the cards. The top and bottom cards of the deck will be checked before and after the move is done for verification.

modifiers.name: backwards
modifiers.description: Sometimes almost impossible, the player must perform their move in reverse, starting with the closer and ending with the opener.

modifiers.name: with your arms crossed
modifiers.description: The player must perform their move with their arms crossed, one over the other. Which arm they choose to cross over which is up to them. If they choose a one-handed move, then the move must be done in both hands simultaneously

modifiers.name: with the cards sideways
modifiers.description: The player must perform the move they've chosen with the cards oriented 90 degrees from how they normally handle them.

modifiers.name: and do 3 moves from this category
upside-down
modifiers.description: The player must now perform the move in a way that it's presented upside-down. This can involve lying on their back or holding the cards above their head so the cards are inverted, or by changing the physics of the move's handling so that is performed upside-down

modifiers.name: but it has to be from a book
modifiers.description: Moves that have been published and taught in printed form. This includes (lecture) notes and eBooks, as well as flourishes that have been taught in magic books and other non-cardist targeted works; however, the player must cite their source when deciding on which move they will be performing. (If they’re found to be full of BS, then they will be banned from playing Showoff for life. Heh.)

modifiers.name: but it has to be from a DVD/VHS
modifiers.description: Moves that have been published and taught on DVD or VHS tapes. This includes flourishes taught on magic DVD/VHS’s; however, the player must cite their source when deciding on which move they will be performing. (If they’re found to be full of BS, then they will be banned from playing Showoff for life. Heh.)

modifiers.name: with your elbows touching
modifiers.description: Self-explanatory

modifiers.name: standing on one leg, on your tip-toes
modifiers.description: Self-explanatory

modifiers.name: but you can’t use your index fingers
modifiers.description: Self-explanatory

modifiers.name: but you can’t use your middle fingers
modifiers.description: Self-explanatory

modifiers.name: but you can’t use your ring fingers
modifiers.description: Self-explanatory

modifiers.name: but you can’t use your hands
modifiers.description: Self-explanatory

modifiers.name: and finish by tearing one card from your deck in half. (Alternatively, lose 1 life and skip this turn.)
modifiers.description: Self-explanatory
